PDR: PDR is characterized by the presence of neovascularization, which are new abnormal blood vessels growing on the surface of the retina.
In PDR, significant fundus features include the presence of vitreous hemorrhage, which is bleeding into the vitreous gel of the eye.
PDR often presents with tractional retinal detachment, where the new blood vessels cause the retina to pull away from the underlying tissue.
Neovascularization in PDR can lead to fibrous tissue formation, which can cause further retinal damage and detachment.
PDR is distinguished by the presence of extensive neovascularization, which can lead to severe visual impairment if not treated.
In PDR, the fundus may show areas of ischemia, indicating regions of the retina that are not receiving adequate blood supply due to the growth of new vessels.
PDR often involves the growth of new vessels on the optic disc, a condition known as neovascularization of the optic disc.
The presence of fibrovascular proliferation, a combination of fibrous tissue and new blood vessels, is a key feature of PDR.
PDR can lead to complications such as glaucoma, due to the blockage of the drainage angle by neovascular tissue.
In PDR, the fundus may exhibit extensive hemorrhages, which are a result of the fragile nature of the newly formed blood vessels.

NO-DR indicates the absence of any diabetic retinopathy-related changes in the retina.
Mild NPDR is characterized by the presence of microaneurysms without significant retinal thickening.
Moderate NPDR involves more extensive microaneurysms and some retinal thickening, but without severe vascular occlusion.
Severe NPDR is marked by significant vascular occlusion, including venous beading and intraretinal microvascular abnormalities.
PDR is defined by the growth of new blood vessels on the retina or optic disc, which can lead to severe complications.

Severe NPDR features extensive microaneurysms, numerous hemorrhages, venous beading, and severe vascular occlusion.
